Very importantly we have to differentiate between the english version of the word "Free".

Libre

Gratuit

fields.notes:
The source was always available with the

Until this time customers did not pay for software or services separately from the very high price for leasing the hardware. Software was provided at no additional charge, generally in source code form;

This "unbundling" gives rise to a multibillion-dollar software and services industry.

fields.helper: "large volumes bug free code": GCC, emacs"

fields.notes:
Freaky genius.

When he was 12, a Science summer-camp counselor who handed Stallman a print-out manual for the IBM 7094.

By the end of summer he was writing out paper programs according to the 7094's internal specifications never having seen a real machine.

years before getting access to his first computer. , Stallman spent the summer after high-school graduation writing his first program, a pre-processor for the 7094 written in the programming language PL/I.

See previous note 1: "As soon as I heard about computers, I wanted to see one and play with one."

---

Single mother, full scholarship to Harvard.

Graduated magna cum laude in Physics

kernel source code available for academic purposes
.. but don't copy, change, derive, resell, etc ...
fields.notes:
%gates # M$ os code for academics >> if you *change* it and omgz if you change and and try to sell those changes - lawyer drop from the sky

Coincidentally these guys are direct contemporaries

They were at Harvard at the same time. But nearly certainly never met as Richards was doing Smart and Bill was doing Law.

Strictly, there is no definition.

# FLOSSD - Free Libre Open-Source (Software Development) (inherited from Tridg)

Some might say that it's the definition provided by the Open Source Initiative (OSI), but they were unfortunately unable to trademark the term.

Anyone who makes their source code available can officially say that their software is open source.

Let's take a step back.

fields.notes:
This talk should always start with beer.

Really quickly want to clear up the terms
fields.content:
What is
"Open Source",
Anyway?

fields.notes:
"Free (to-use-change-and-redistribute) Software"

FOSS, FLOSS, FOSSD

Free Libre Open Source Development

When I say open source I mean "Free" as in free to skip and jump, free to learn from and redistribute as you will.

---

Some people really care about the difference between terms. It's not important here.

Usually when I give this talk I go on about how software projects vary beyond description.

But actually Python projects are all pretty similar.

Don't be imaginative. Just don't bother.

An information source that's public and open. Eg, a Newspaper.

The term open source was appropriated in this way during the early tech-boom because business people could just not stand the idea of "Free" (even in the speech) sense is/was an anathema to them.
fields.content:
In a Netscape boardroom in 1998

(Eric Raymond was there)

63 Recognised Licenses

Apache License; BSD;
Eclipse Public License;
GPL and LGPL; MIT license;
Mozilla Public License 2.0;

A Copyright License is a
promise not to sue.

(Rather than a permit to do something.)

Can also set conditions.

fields.helper: "all the fruits in the forest are poisonous"
fields.notes: %poisonivy-octocat %::15%/25% $ "all the fruits in the forest are poisonous" # very clear no licence, no go! (github) (all the fruits in the forest are poisonous) - 15% of all repositories had license files (Armin Ronacher) - 25% of those have the license only mentioned in the Readme file - if you're not sure, assume your work is derived and: - inherit license - don't use
fields.content:
15% of all repositories had license files
(ie: 85% are not FOSS)

If you're not sure:

Assume your work is Derived

Inherit the original license.
or
Don't copy the software.

fields.helper: Never has the little guy lost.
fields.content:
% copyleft
$ must return changes; must stay GPL
# Copyleft
- must return changes
- must stay GPL
  >> GPL is price of admission
  >> will make big corp do boring bits
- it doesn't really matter at low level, but at scale, it'll matter

# Python 2% (Black Duck, ohloh, @mako)
  >> no offense guys
  - ~335K/ 1% active (0.7%/0.4% high/very high)

- why Licenses: because legally noone is allowed without
# Copyleft does what it can to save us from exploitation
- Eben Moglin: 9:1 hardware
- Bill Joy: embarrassed for us
- seriously consider proper copyleft: LGPL/Eclipse/MPL
- MPLv2 came out late 2012
- don't have to enforce, but have the option, hard to change license later

Every last major tech company is involved in the the OSI sense now.

fields.notes:
